questions.question_text: Which of the following Ethernet cables would BEST support an application that requires a 600Mbps throughput at the lowest price point?

discussion.content:
The answer is CAT 5e : 

CAT 5: 100 Mbps
CAT 5e: 1000 Mbps (1 Gbps)
Funny thing is that cat6 is so standard now that ive seen it for less than cat 5e!
the answer is cat 5e , cat 5 only supports up to 100 mbps.

comments.content:
no they aren't 
 5 100 MHz 100 Mbps 100 m (328 ft) 100BASE-TX
5e 100 MHz 1 Gbps 100 m (328 ft) 1000BASE-T
6 250 MHz 1 Gbps 100 m (328 ft) 1000BASE-T
6 250 MHz 10 Gbps 55 m (180 ft) 10GBASE-T
6A 500 MHz 10 Gbps 100 m (328 ft) 10GBASE-T
wrong, cat 5 supports 100 baseTX and 1000 baseT

The old-fashioned Cat 5 cable is no longer a recognized standard, but it technically supports gigabit speeds--just not well. Cat 5e cable is enhanced to reduce interference so that it can reliably deliver gigabit speeds. However, Gigabit Ethernet still pushes the cable to its limits.

discussion.content: how is the answer B, is cat 5e cable cheaper than cat 5 cable?, isnt it it that both cat 5 and 5e are rated at the same speed?

Cables, especially internet or information sharing ones are important to understand. You'll be making custom ones in unique situations, checking switches and routers, and often picking the right tool for a job. It's critical to have a good understanding of even the boring, rudimentary aspects of tech in IT because picking the right cable may save a lot of money, time, and picking the wrong cable is downright embarrassing!

questions.question_text: A technician is using PXE to upgrade the OS in a lab that has new and old computers. The new devices can obtain a DHCP address but fail to locate the PXE server. The old computers can locate the PXE server and upgrade the OS as required. Which of the following is MOST likely preventing the new computers from booting to PXE?

discussion.content:
When enabled and fully configured, Secure Boot helps a computer resist attacks and infection from malware. Secure Boot detects tampering with boot loaders, key operating system files, and unauthorized option ROMs by validating their digital signatures.

Preboot execution environment (PXE), pronounced pixie, is a set of standards that enables a computer to load an operating system (OS) over a network connection. PXE can be used to quickly install an OS and is commonly used for both servers and clients.

comments.content: We use this at work and I've been wondering why we use it since the first day. Thanks!
